Award.AwardTitle: BD&I: MoveBank: Integrated database for networked organism tracking.
Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of the State of New York is awarded a grant to develop MoveBank, an integrated animal tracking research system for the the research community consisting of a reliable data acquisition and ingestion system, data stream processing and data mining analytics, and extensible architecture that supports various resource sharing models. The project is design to serve a growing global community of animal tracking researchers interested in collaboration. It will have interfaces to facilitate state-of-the-art of data analysis, mining, modeling and visualization tools. The museum will collaborate with Princeton University, the San Diego Supercomputer Center at University of California San Diego and the University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign.

Studying animal movement is of critical importance to addressing environmental challenges including invasive species, infectious diseases, climate and land-use change. New tracking technologies are allowing more researchers to collect more data more easily, but science lacks the cyberinfrastructure to acquire and manage data in a scalable and reliable fashion and need tools to efficiently analyze and integrate these disparate datasets. This situation is made more challenging by the development of environmental observatories that are generating (or promise to generate) extremely large spatially-explicit datasets with automated methods, including GPS, Automated Radio Telemetry Systems (ARTS), and motion-triggered camera networks. The integration of legacy tracking databases together with real-time observatory data streams has the potential to fundamentally advance the science of animal tracking and animal-based environmental forecasting.

Institution.Name: The University of the State of New York
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF THE STATE OF NEW YORK

Performance_Institution.Name: The University of the State of New York

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF funded Movebank project combined the work of biologist, data miners, and experts in cyberinfrastructure to create new tools and knowledge about how animals move on and around the globe.  One of the main outcomes was the creation of an online tracking resource at www.Movebank.org.  This site serves as an archive, analysis tool, and data sharing tool for biologist tracking animals, and the natural resource managers or general public interested in learning about animals.  Scientists can upload data themselves, or stream them in live through ARGOS satellites. We also provide sophisticated viewing of data through an integrated Google-maps interface, or through animated Google earth files.  The site also offers robust data protection options, so that trackers can share their data publicly, or only with selected Movebank users.  Finally, we have recently provided a tool that allows users to link their animal tracking data directly to a global database of weather, to obtain the conditions that there animal was experiencing, at that particular place and time. Over the life of this grant we have slowly increased the usage of this site, starting with Movebank staff, then adding a few key collaborators, then adding participants of our three tracking workshops.  This slow increase has allowed us to deal with bugs and functionality in a stepwise fashion. Through this effort Movebank users have added over 28 million data points from 17,445 individually tracked animals representing 189 species contributed by 378 studies.  Approximately 10 million data points are locations estimated from five different tracking technologies, with another 18 Million data points coming from on-board sensors associated with the tracking tags, especially accelerometers.

            We have also worked to develop similar tools for scientists using camera traps to study animal movement, creating a new interactive website called Smithsonian Wild (siwild.si.edu).  Since its launch in Feb 2011 this site has been very popular attracting >1 million unique views from >340,000 unique visitors from 186 countries. We are still working towards establishing an online dynamic database that scientists and citizen scientists can use to manage and share their camera trapping data. We expect to have a first working prototype released in 2012.  This work is funded, in part, by a new NSF Macrosystems ecology grant.

            Another aspect of our project was to develop scalable and analytical infrastructure for accessing and mining animal movement data, including mining swarm patterns and periodic patterns for moving objects, and construction of MoveMine system prototype.  These new algorithms and implementations are useful for the study of any moving objects, be they animals, humans, or hurricanes. 

            We have also developed new tracking tools on the hardware and data flow side, including an automated telemetry system with live data flow at the Smithsonian’s research site in Panama, a real-time data viewer that uses DataTurbine to stream live tracking data, and an accelerometer informed GPS tracking tag.

            Our research has been shared widely through over 50 peer review articles, dozens of popular articles, hundreds of news stories, and televised documentaries. The results of this grant have also been used by natural resource managers at various levels including local (Albany Pine Bush Preserve Commission), regional (New York State Department of Environmental Conservation), national (U.S. Congress), and international officials (United Nations Con...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The NSF funded Movebank project combined the work of biologist, data miners, and experts in cyberinfrastructure to create new tools and knowledge about how animals move on and around the globe. One of the main outcomes was the creation of an online tracking resource at www.Movebank.org. This site serves as an archive, analysis tool, and data sharing tool for biologist tracking animals, and the natural resource managers or general public interested in learning about animals. Scientists can upload data themselves, or stream them in live through ARGOS satellites. We also provide sophisticated viewing of data through an integrated Google-maps interface, or through animated Google earth files. The site also offers robust data protection options, so that trackers can share their data publicly, or only with selected Movebank users. Finally, we have recently provided a tool that allows users to link their animal tracking data directly to a global database of weather, to obtain the conditions that there animal was experiencing, at that particular place and time. Over the life of this grant we have slowly increased the usage of this site, starting with Movebank staff, then adding a few key collaborators, then adding participants of our three tracking workshops. This slow increase has allowed us to deal with bugs and functionality in a stepwise fashion. Through this effort Movebank users have added over 28 million data points from 17,445 individually tracked animals representing 189 species contributed by 378 studies. Approximately 10 million data points are locations estimated from five different tracking technologies, with another 18 Million data points coming from on-board sensors associated with the tracking tags, especially accelerometers. We have also worked to develop similar tools for scientists using camera traps to study animal movement, creating a new interactive website called Smithsonian Wild (siwild.si.edu). Since its launch in Feb 2011 this site has been very popular attracting >1 million unique views from >340,000 unique visitors from 186 countries. We are still working towards establishing an online dynamic database that scientists and citizen scientists can use to manage and share their camera trapping data. We expect to have a first working prototype released in 2012. This work is funded, in part, by a new NSF Macrosystems ecology grant. Another aspect of our project was to develop scalable and analytical infrastructure for accessing and mining animal movement data, including mining swarm patterns and periodic patterns for moving objects, and construction of MoveMine system prototype. These new algorithms and implementations are useful for the study of any moving objects, be they animals, humans, or hurricanes. We have also developed new tracking tools on the hardware and data flow side, including an automated telemetry system with live data flow at the SmithsonianÆs research site in Panama, a real-time data viewer that uses DataTurbine to stream live tracking data, and an accelerometer informed GPS tracking tag. Our research has been shared widely through over 50 peer review articles, dozens of popular articles, hundreds of news stories, and televised documentaries. The results of this grant have also been used by natural resource managers at various levels including local (Albany Pine Bush Preserve Commission), regional (New York State Department of Environmental Conservation), national (U.S. Congress), and international officials (United Nations Convention on Migratory Species).
